message: The site is a community of programmers, designers, and IT pros. I really respect how HN has kept the quality so high through the years as it got popular. So I wanted to get tips from the HN community on how to build a good community and preserve quality. What do you think are the ways to do that? What is the most important?
if most of your users behave in the way you want, new users will use their behaviour as cues, rapid expansion means new users cueing off other new users, which can be bad
"Good fences make good neighbours" is a good adage for communities imo
(but if all those users are coming from somewhere else that is aligned with your style, such as HN, then maybe it wouldn't be so bad a problem)
if people are encouraged to  behave in a certain way, they will... the same user will act like a 'tard when on 4chan, and post intelligently on HN, because they have different "fences"

the other thing is to be careful of rapid expansion - one community I built exploded, 100% growth day on day for 3 days, and it killed it; there weren't enough users used to the rules and fences to influence the behaviour of the new users
Talentopoly is on the front page of HackerNews http://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=2271302

@jaredbrown np :) I've helped in some capacity or another with a few small-to-medium-sized communities, most of my advice is based on what I've seen fail rather than what I've seen succeed so take with a pinch of salt, it's not fully tested ;)
@ZoFreX, I'd love to pick your brain further. Can I DM you on Twitter? You can find me @jaredbrown.
@ZoFreX I DM'ed you my email address on Twitter
